questions.uddipok:
Change the sentences according to directions:-
(a) William Wordsworth is one of the best wellknown poets in English literature (Positive).
(b) He was the second of his father's five sons (Negative).
(c) He was born at Cumberland on April 4, 1770 (Complex).
(d) When he was eight years old, his mother died (Simple).
(e) At the same year he was sent to the Grammar School of Hawkshead for education (Compound).
(f) He was only 13 years old when his father died (Interrogative).
(g) Fundamental education had been given to him at the school (Active).
(h) The education that he learnt from this institution played a better role in his life (Simple).
(i) The readers called for a new edition of his famous book "The Lyrical Ballads" in 1800 (Passive).
(j) This book brought a huge name and fame in his life (Exclamatory).

sub_questions.explanation:
(a) Very few poets in English literature are as wellknown as William Wordsworth.
(b) Wasn't he the second of his father's five sons./ He was none but the second of his father's five sons.
(c) It was on April 4, 1770 when he was born at Cumberland.
(d) His mother died at his eight.
(e) At the same year he was sent to a school for education and the name of the school was the Grammar School of Hawkshead.
(f) Wasn't he only 13 years old when his father died?
(g) The school had given him fundamental education.
(h) The education learnt from this institution played a better role in his life.
(i) A new edition of his famous book "The Lyrical Ballads" was called for by the readers in 1800.
(j) What a huge name and fame in his life this book brought!

questions.uddipok: Load-shedding has become a part of our daily life. It paralyses our way of life in many ways. Now, write a paragraph in 250 words on 'Load Shedding'.

sub_questions.explanation: Load-shedding is a recurring issue in our daily lives, particularly in countries with inadequate power generation or poor infrastructure. It refers to the deliberate interruption of electricity supply to manage demand when it exceeds the available supply. While it may be necessary to prevent overloading the system, its impact on everyday life is profound and disruptive. Load-shedding paralyzes various aspects of our routines. Students, for instance, suffer immensely as they are forced to study in dim light or suspend their studies altogether. Businesses and industries also bear the brunt, as factories cannot operate machinery, resulting in reduced productivity and financial losses. Moreover, households face numerous inconveniences, such as disrupted cooking, lack of access to clean water due to non-functional pumps, and discomfort during extreme weather conditions when fans or air conditioners cease to work. Health services are another critical area affected; hospitals often face challenges running essential equipment, putting patients' lives at risk. Small vendors and shopkeepers lose sales as customers prefer well-lit areas to shop. Load-shedding also affects public safety since prolonged power outages can lead to an increase in theft and other crimes in poorly lit areas. The problem stems from insufficient power generation, high electricity demand, and technical faults in the grid system. While using alternative energy sources like solar panels, generators, and UPS systems provides temporary relief, a sustainable solution requires significant investment in infrastructure and renewable energy. Until then, load-shedding will remain a pressing challenge, disrupting progress and daily life.

questions.uddipok: Write a composition on 'Wonders of Modern Science'.

sub_questions.explanation:
Science means knowledge gained through experiment and research. Science does many things for the development of human civilization. The modern age is a gift of science. We are passing our days under the great influence of science.
We see the influence of science at every step of our life. It has changed the way we live. It has invented many things for our comfort. Today we feel the presence of science in our everyday life. The pen we write with, the shirt we put on, the bicycle we ride all are the invention of science. With the touch of a switch, we get our lights dazzling, fans whirling and radios and televisions singing and talking.
The invention of electricity has brought about a revolutionary change in the history of human civilization. Electricity helps to operate machine, factories and other heavy industries. Electric fans, lights, and heaters have made our life more enjoyable.
Moreover, our agricultural and industrial development is fully dependent on modern science. We now cultivate our land with power tillers. The production of crops is increasing day by day with the help of chemical fertilizers and insecticides. Science also helps us in inventing new hybrid seeds. In industrial areas, science has made a significant contribution. From needles to rockets, everything produced in industry is the contribution of science.
Communication is considered the motion of life. Science has brought about a great change in our communication system also. Invention of speedy transports like bus, train, airplane, truck, ship etc. has made transportation faster and comfortable. Rocket and space shuttle are great wonders of modern science. By using them, man has already conquered the moon and is now preparing for the Mars. Besides, satellite television has added a new dimension to our communication system. It has brought the whole world to our living room. Moreover, telephone, FAX, E-mail, cellular phone, and internet have turned the whole world into a global village. We can instantly communicate with our friends and family through them.
In the medical field, science has done unbelievable improvements. Blood transfusion and transplantation of other organs have become possible with the help of science. The invention of X-ray, ECG, Ultrasonography, penicillin, CT scan, biopsy, various life-saving antibiotic, etc. has worked wonders in the field of medical science. Modern medical science has given eyes to the blind, hearing to the deaf, legs to the lame and what not.
However, the inventions of science could also be destructive also if they are misused. By inventing atom bomb, hydrogen bomb, missiles, and other explosives, men are now destroying the human race and its beautiful creation in the world. The destruction caused by dropping atom bombs in Hiroshima and Nagasaki during World War II bears testimony to it.
In conclusion, the wonders of science cannot be described in words. But if it is misused, it brings destruction. So, it should be utilised for the greater benefit of human beings.
